arguments.claim: Section 25A(3) only applies where HUF existed and income was of the family; nothing precludes ITO from assessing as individual if no HUF or income separate

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 3 postulates the existence of a family which has been assessed as a Hindu undivided family. arguments.claim: Whether discretion of Tribunal properly exercised in refusing new question is a question of law; here properly exercised as not raised earlier

anchor.surface_text: Whether the discretion of the Tribunal has been properly exercised in a given case in refusing to allow a question to be raised which has not been set forth in the memorandum of appeal, would normally be a question of law. In the present case, not only was the question not raised in the memorandum of appeal, but was not even set up before the Income-tax

arguments.claim: There is no evidence that income assessed under s.34(1)(a) was not his separate income; cannot presume it was HUF income

anchor.surface_text: There is no evidence on the record that the income which is assessed in proceedings under section 34(1)(a) was not his separate income, and from the fact that the original assessment was made on the footing of an undivided family in the year of account, it cannot be presumed in proceedings for assessment under section 34 that the income assessed was not of an individual.

holdings.text: The Tribunal did not err in law in refusing to allow the petitioner to raise and argue the question whether the reassessment as an individual was invalid given the original assessment as Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the discretion of the Tribunal has been properly exercised in a given case in refusing to allow a question to be raised which has not been set forth in the memorandum of appeal, would normally be a question of law. In the present case, not only was the question not raised in the memorandum of appeal, but was not even set up before the Income-tax

holdings.reasoning_summary: Point not raised before ITO or AAC, not in grounds of appeal per rule 12, and requires investigation of fresh facts; discretion properly exercised.

holdings.text: The discretion of the Tribunal was properly exercised in refusing to allow a new question not set forth in the memorandum of appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the discretion of the Tribunal has been properly exercised in a given case in refusing to allow a question to be raised which has not been set forth in the memorandum of appeal, would normally be a question of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Such discretion reviewable as question of law; here proper as point never raised earlier or in appeal memo.

holdings.text: Section 25A(3) obliges the Income-tax Officer to assess income of HUF members as HUF only where such a family existed and the income earned was of the family.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 3 postulates the existence of a family which has been assessed as a Hindu undivided family. It is only where such family existed and the income earned was of the family that the Income-tax Officer is obliged to assess the income of the members of the family in the status of a Hindu undivided family, notwithstanding a plea that a partition has taken place among the members.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.25A(3): postulates prior existence of assessed HUF and family income; no bar otherwise.

holdings.text: Nothing in the Act precludes the Income-tax Officer from assessing escaped income as belonging to an individual notwithstanding a prior assessment in the status of Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: But there is nothing in the Act which precludes the Income-tax Officer from coming to a conclusion that even though in the previous year the assessment was made on the footing that the assessee was a Hindu undivided family, there was in fact no Hindu undivided family and the income for the purpose of assessment belonged to an individual,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.25A(3) does not preclude; ITO can conclude no HUF or income individual despite prior assessment.

holdings.text: There is no presumption in section 34 reassessment proceedings that income is of a Hindu undivided family merely because the original assessment was made on that footing.

anchor.surface_text: There is no evidence on the record that the income which is assessed in proceedings under section 34(1)(a) was not his separate income, and from the fact that the original assessment was made on the footing of an undivided family in the year of account, it cannot be presumed in proceedings for assessment under section 34 that the income assessed was not of an individual.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence income not separate; cannot presume HUF income from prior assessment footing.

holdings.text: The new plea raised before the Tribunal necessitated enquiry into fresh facts regarding existence of HUF and whether the income was of the family.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, unable to accept the argument of Mr. Pathak that the new plea sought to be raised did not necessitate enquiry into facts which had not been investigated. The new plea is based on a two-fold assumption of facts - that a Hindu undivided family existed in the relevant previous year and that the income which was sought to be assessed in proceedings under section 34(1)(a) was the income of that family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plea assumes HUF existence (needs evidence) and income of family (contrary to assessee's individual return and admission).

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 3 postulates the existence of a family which has been assessed as a Hindu undivided family. It is only where such family existed and the income earned was of the family that the Income-tax Officer is obliged to assess the income of the members of the family in the status of a Hindu undivided family, notwithstanding a plea that a partition has taken place among the members.

The High Court recorded an answer in the negative on that question. With special leave, Manji Dana has appealed to this court. anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, unable to accept the argument of Mr. Pathak that the new plea sought to be raised did not necessitate enquiry into facts which had not been investigated. The new plea is based on a two-fold assumption of facts - that a Hindu undivided family existed in the relevant previous year and that the income which was sought to be assessed in proceedings under section 34(1)(a) was the income of that family.
